instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.820-3476: What is 820-3476? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S4: What is PP5V_S4? PP5V_S4 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Hi again, I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board that started at 26mA for a while, I was testing voltages and at some point, it jumped to 150mA

I was originally missing <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4</SIGNAL> on L7520 but then once it jumped to 150mA it was present.

L7320 & L7310 seem a little low at 1.7V instead of 1.8V?

<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> there is no <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> but checking L7095 <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is present.

I have also attached thermal images of the board

Thanks for your help

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message:
Broken trace to pin 8/<CHIP>U1950</CHIP>; rebuild it.
Post voltage at all its pins.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3476</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A
threads.message: That was the problem, thank you.
